Mr. Speaker, the proliferation of drugs in our communities, school yards and playgrounds has become the calamity of the 1990s. Our youth have become the prime target for the drug trade which not only saps their youth but all too often causes anguish for the families involved.
The increase in the illegal drug trade in metro Toronto, accompanied by the related violence, has worsened of late and has stretched the resources of our local police forces to their limits.
In an effort to help those on the front lines continue their battle against drugs, I urge the government to amend the Narcotics Control Act and share the seized assets as a result of a drug conviction with the local police forces and community organizations, instead of returning all moneys to general revenues.

Along with York West constituents who have helped collect thousands of signatures on petitions to support this campaign, I call upon the government to immediately act upon this community initiative and help end this plague.
This problem will be won or lost on the local battlefields and therefore those waging the fight locally must be given the tools with which to overcome and to ensure victory.

Mr. Speaker, as we are on the countdown to the Olympics which officially begin this weekend, I would like to commend and wish our athletes well.
Many of us, including golfers and/or tennis players, took heart with what our Davis Cup team almost did in Vancouver last weekend. Our athletes at Albertville in the Alps are looking and dreaming of their gold, their bronze and their silver. I think it is only correct that as we are spaced out in this country on constitutions that we know we have those athletes who are not spaced out on constitutions but are spaced out on their own physical achievements. We wish them well.
We in this House, Mr. Speaker, deserve special credit because the daughter of a colleague of mine, the hon. member for Calgary Northeast, is on the official Olympic team as a freestyle skier. We wish her and all her companions well. They have faith in themselves, they have faith in their country. We have faith in them, we have faith in this country. We put our hopes in them and we wish them well.

Mr. Speaker, the town of Amherst was shocked to learn of the planned closing of Amherst Aerovox, a subsidiary of an American firm. After the initial shock, the town and area are gathering up its resources and fighting back.
Already the Amherst Aerovox Community Committee has raised $100,000 to be used to search for products,
partners or new owners for this factory. The team is made up of local business and development people who have knowledge of the industry and contacts which hopefully will prove successful in finding a solution.
The provincial Department of Economic Development is assisting with funding, resource people and material. The federal Department of Industry, Science and Technology has also provided information and assistance. The Cumberland Development Authority is acting as central office for the group. The Amherst and Area Development Commission has provided funding and manpower. The company has added funding as well. Canada Employment and Immigration is providing an industrial adjustment program to help the employees adjust and ACOA has acted quickly and significantly to provide funding and resources.
The search for products, partners and matching businesses has begun and will continue until a solution is found. We will leave no stone unturned to solve this issue in the interests of the 62 employees affected.
 * *

Mr. Speaker, this is International Development Week in Canada. Again, Development Week falls in the midst of a global recession but this is not the time for Canada to reduce her budget for ODA.
This recession is hurting Canadians deeply, however, as usual the hardest hit are the world's poorest. Rarely have developing countries needed our help more than now.
The United Nations Development Program continues to highlight dramatic disparities between North and South, and UNICEF tells us that one quarter of a million children died last year from starvation or disease.
Canada must not back away from her obligations to the developing world. We must ensure that our development assistance provides the greatest possible benefit to the recipients. The government must work more closely with Canada's development NGOs to ensure that our ODA goals are met.
February 4, 1992

As final preparations are made for the budget, the government must be reminded of the negative effects for Canada and for developing countries of any cuts or dilution of Canadian ODA. As Canadians, we can make a difference if our government will help us.

Mr. Speaker, we are off to a bad start for Canada's 125th birthday.
When invitations for the festivities were sent out to Canadians, Quebec's anglophone Canadians received theirs in French only, and one million francophones outside Quebec received theirs in English only. Was this an oversight?
Mr. Speaker, the fact remains that this country has two official languages, and we should respect that fact. One would expect an agency receiving $50 million from the federal government through the responsible department, the Department of the Secretary of State, to do better than that.
The government argues that the organizing committee is independent and accountable only to itself, but the fact remains that it is spending public funds. I think the Official Languages Committee, which has not met since last October, should shed some light on this matter and prevent further unfortunate incidents of this kind. This is an invitation to celebrate Canada's birthday, which is celebrated in both official languages of this country.

Mr. Speaker, the Aur Resources mine in Abitibi, which is part of the Aur-Lou-vem group, will be operational in 1994, as soon as the infrastructures have been built: two exploration shafts, one pithead and one concentrator with a capacity of
5,000	tons per day.
This represents an investment of $326 million that will stimulate the economy of Val d'Or, located about ten kilometres from the mine. It is expected that 500 well-paying jobs will be created immediately, and the spin-offs of the exploration costs are estimated at $950 million over 14 years.
Mr. James Gill, president of Aur, seems to have succeeded in financing the mine without losing control
over the company or diluting its stock. This was a complex operation that required months of negotiation.
Mr. Speaker, the mine's proven reserves are expected to produce revenues totalling $2 billion in Canadian funds during the 14 years it is expected to be in operation.
It is the biggest deposit ever found in this country since the Hemlo deposit was found in northeastern Ontario in the early 80s.

Mr. Speaker, the procedure of the environmental assessment hearings into the construction of three additional runways at Canada's most overcrowded airport, Pearson International in Tbronto, is quickly drawing to a close. Presentations to the review panel note that Pearson is at its capacity and noise is intolerable.
Transport Canada says the new runways will solve all the problems, but it fails to understand that 3, 5,10 or 15 new runways will not make a bit of difference. The runways will allow more planes to fly in and out but passengers will not be able to board or deplane because there are not enough gates for the planes.
There is an opportunity to be had here. Instead of wasting millions on new runways at Pearson, Hamilton airport can be developed to handle more air traffic. A GO link could shuttle passengers quickly between Hamilton and Pearson International as is done in other major centres around the world.
Transport Canada and this government must develop a multimodal strategy on transportation with a view to future need, not short-term political gain.

Mr. Speaker, last Sunday I had the honour of attending a luncheon in Toronto hosted by businessman John Bitove to meet Macedonian President Kiro Gligo-rov. President Gligorov was elected to head the newly independent Republic of Macedonia on January 27, 1991.

February 4, 1992
In 1944, Macedonia was taken over by the federal Yugoslav government. Finally, after a long, suffering struggle spanning almost five decades, Macedonia held a referendum on independence and declared itself independent on November 17, 1991. The overwhelming results freed Macedonia from the shackles of communism and the yoke of Yugoslavia.
It is time for Canada to recognize this proud, independent republic. Without the world's recognition, Macedonians cannot be properly represented on the world stage.

Mr. Speaker, the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation and our government have just taken a timely initiative that will enable 200,000 Canadians to own a home, by allowing a down payment of 5 per cent instead of 10 per cent to buy a house. This will benefit over 200,000 Canadians, including thousands of Quebecers, who, especially in isolated regions, did not have the income that was previously required for home ownership.
Furthermore, Mr. Speaker, this favorable measure will help get the economy out of our present recession. This finally shows our government's great ability in taking tough measures to fight inflation and to lower interest rates when they were called for. It was unthinkable to bring in such a measure any sooner. However, this government can present incentives for home ownership. I say bravo. There will be more in the budget.

Mr. Speaker, today is Chinese New Year. Chinese Canadians are celebrating the Year of the Monkey while Vietnamese Canadians celebrate Tete.
The past year has seen more Chinese families reunited through immigration, business investments have increased and young Chinese Canadians continue to excel in scholarship and in professions. Canadians of Chinese origin are making a rich contribution to our multicultural Canada.
Chinese New Year is a time of hope and renewal. Chinese Canadians have waited patiently and worked hard for recognition of past injustices that early settlers suffered as a result of the racist head tax and the Chinese exclusion act. Once again, I call on the government to acknowledge these injustices with appropriate redress.
I also urge all parties to support constitutional amendments that will protect minorities from future discrimination.
May the Year of the Monkey bring a renewed Canada with health, happiness and prosperity for all Canadians. Kong Hai Fatt Choy.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday the government approved a plan to allow firsttime home buyers to get 95 per cent financing on their real estate purchase.
That is great news. What was not so great was the attempt of the Leader of the Opposition to claim credit for an idea the government has been working on for a very long time. Canadians do not care where the ideas come from. They just want good ones.
Five per cent down is good, as long as home buyers are careful not to over-mortgage themselves. The lowest mortgage rates in over two decades is also a good idea, making this an excellent time to buy.
Finally, being able to use RRSP funds for first-time home purchases is another good idea, supported by many MPs on both sides of the House. We all urge the finance minister to listen, to reflect and just do it in the next budget.

Mr. Speaker, yes, this week has been proclaimed International Development Week, but it will only be meaningful if the government commits and restates its policy targets of directing Canadian aid to benefit the poorest populations in developing nations.

Linking human rights to aid is laudatory, but only if those already oppressed are not further victimized. It cannot be used as an excuse to cut back on Canada's total aid budget nor cynically to target those developing countries for linked cutbacks that do not bring immediate economic benefits through trade to Canada.
When determining aid policies particular regard must be given to recipient government budgets and policies, their military versus social expenditures, women and child support initiatives, and environment and population problems. The economics of globalization must not continue to dominate our development efforts. Aid must not be conditional to a debt ridden country accepting punitive structural adjustment measures. The emphasis must be put on more substantive debt relief to the world's poorest countries, particularly those in Africa, and on direct poverty alleviation through health and education programs.
Canada's and global security depend on our continuing commitment to the poor of the world. International Development Week can be an important opportunity to strengthen Canadian resolve to that end.

Mr. Speaker, $5,000 is now enough to buy a $100,000 house.
The federal government, through the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation, is doing its part to help individuals own a home.
The Loan Insurance Program for new home owners will reduce the minimum down payment required for buyers of a first house, whether new or previously built, from 10 per cent to 5 per cent for mortgage loans insured by the Canadian government.
This initiative, which takes effect immediately, will boost the construction industry in Canada for the next two years and give about 200,000 Canadian households which now rent their accommodation the chance to own their home.
Together with lower interest rates and the present state of the real estate market, this program should
stimulate the economy and increase the chances of home ownership for many Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, small business is under considerable strain today for a variety of reasons, one of which I strongly believe is the paper burden we place upon it. Small businesses in my constituency continue to press me to get our government to attack this problem.
I am well aware of the commendable efforts being undertaken by my colleague, the hon. Minister of State for Small Businesses and Tourism. We must not only support his initiatives but assist his efforts by providing feedback to his department from all constituents.
I urge all members of this House to participate in this effort, not to only facilitate productivity and growth in our small business sector but to reduce our costs as well.

Mr. Speaker, prior to the free trade agreement coming into effect in January 1989, Employment Canada had a unit that was responsible for collecting information. Regional offices would phone in daily any closures occurring. This unit was cut due to government cutbacks just prior to the free trade agreement.
Once the free trade agreement was in place, demand for information increased and the government produced a report every two weeks.
In trying to track down this list recently I found that there is only one being compiled. In fact Labour Canada uses this list for its purposes. For example, earlier this month Labour Canada requested a list of closures in Quebec and a handwritten list was supplied.
I think my question is one that we all must ponder. Is the government trying to hide how many permanent lay-offs and lost jobs there have been due to the free trade agreement? If it is not, it has a responsibility to make sure not just parliamentarians but all Canadians know what permanent lay-offs have taken place.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean J. Charest (Minister of the Environment):

We have reduced by 45 per cent the amount of CFCs going into the atmosphere. As a result of that we are now four years ahead of schedule according to what the Montreal protocol has set as a deadline. We think that we can in fact go faster than that. At the meeting of the countries involved in the Montreal protocol next November we will be pressing other countries to accelerate the phase-out of CFCs. Canada intends to maintain that leadership position.
I recently announced, I think it was in August, a $25 million initiative to assist us in meeting our objectives. Among the initiatives announced in August was in fact an initiative that will enable the Government of Canada to put out warnings of ultraviolet rays. speechtext:

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am rather surprised at the comments of the hon. member for Lac Saint-Jean. He ought to know that our position in January was the same as it was on December 20. We still support strengthening and clarifying GATT article XI. It is a vital measure that has allowed our marketing boards to operate for years.
The Canadian position was a joint effort. We prepared that position with Canadian farm leaders. I have on many occasions met with farm producers, even in the hon. member's riding, where I had a chance to visit quite often. I have met practically all the producers in his riding. Quebec producers especially are in a position to know that we defend the interests of Quebec producers and that we will continue to do so. There is nothing to be worried about on that score.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
What matters, Mr. Speaker, is the final position. And the final position is that this government accepted the Dunkel Report, while expressing some mild disappointment about parts it found less palatable. Mr. Speaker, the minister knows perfectly well this about-face will dismantle crop insurance and the mechanisms for setting prices for milk, eggs and poultry.
The minister knows perfectly well this will cost farm producers in Quebec at least $350 million over the next six years. So tearing up his shirt is just not enough, and the minister should tell the House what he intends to do to save thousands of Quebec producers from disaster.

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as far as about-faces are concerned, I think the hon. member is quite knowledgeable on that score. I don't need any lessons from him.
Mr. Speaker, Canada's position has not changed. Canada did not accept the Dunkel report. When the hon. member says what he said just now, he is mistaken. I don't think he did it on purpose. He was probably misinformed. We are defending the interests of farm producers, Mr. Speaker, and we will continue to do so. And I think the hon. member should stop spreading information which, as he knows perfectly well, does not reflect the real situation, Mr. Speaker.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development. During the Oka crisis in 1990, the regional director at the time signed a letter committing the government to acquiring the properties located in the Jardins d'Oka and south of Highway 344. Mr. Speaker, I hope the minister realizes my constituents are upset because they have yet to receive a formal proposal for dealing with the serious psychological and financial problems they experienced as a result of the invasion of their property and land by masked warriors.
Could the minister confirm he is about to submit proposals to these owners and to the municipality of the village of Oka? And when will he do so?

speakeroldname: Hon. Thomas Siddon (Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first I would like to compliment the hon. member for Argenteuil-Papineau for the diligent work she has done, together with the Minister of State for Indian Affairs, to seek a solution to this veiy difficult problem.
I can confirm that indeed a very creative proposal has been brought together by our officials and is presently being discussed among the four parties to an agreement with respect to the land issues at Kanesatake and Oka. I believe this proposal will be of great benefit to the land owners she speaks of and to the Mohawk community at Kanesatake.
As soon as the preliminary discussions are completed, further details will be forthcoming.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Finance.
In the Montreal area, the total number of housing starts has dropped 15 per cent, compared with last year. Yesterday the government co-opted a proposal made by the Leader of the Opposition when it announced that it was reducing the downpayment required to buy a first house from 10 to 5 per cent.
February 4, 1992

Is the Minister of Finance willing to implement another component of the Liberal platform that would allow Canadians to use up to $7,500 of their Registered Retirement Savings Plan for the purchase of a new home?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think the hon. member will admit that the government has already taken a large number of very positive measures, more than were taken by the Liberal government when it was in power several years ago during another recession.
I suggest he look at the interest rate levels we have today which have given us our lowest mortgage rates in 20 years. That is a positive contribution.
Dropping inflation plus the measure announced by my colleague yesterday are pointing us in the right direction.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Jean Cantin, director general of the Association de la construction du Quebec for the Montreal area, said that the option of using RRSP funds for the purchase of a first home would have a far greater impact than reducing the initial downpayment from 10 per cent to 5 per cent.
Considering the extent of the recession, Mr. Speaker, is the government prepared to commit itself to introducing legislation that would allow Canadians to buy their first home with the money they put in a retirement savings plan?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if the hon. member had paid attention to the results of the conference of finance ministers in Quebec City a few days ago, he would have heard my colleague, the Minister of Finance, point out that we were going to give this matter active consideration.
Perhaps the hon. member would care to recall some of the comments on this use of RRSPs, which were intended to help Canadians save enough money for their retirement. We must be very careful about the way this money is used. Other provinces have told us they had a housing surplus.
We are now looking at all these factors, and we will let you know what we decide in due time.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources.
The seriousness of the economic recession is evident in every community throughout the country. We have had the recent announcement of Imperial Oil laying off 1,700 workers and just minutes ago we learned that Gulf Canada Resources is pulling out of the Hibernia project because of the bad economic environment.
I want to ask the minister of energy whether or not he can confirm this particular information and if he can assure this House that every step will be taken to ensure that the Hibernia project will proceed without any delay whatsoever.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jake Epp (Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources):
speakerposition: Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to thank the hon. member for the question.
I can confirm that Gulf Canada Resources served notice of withdrawal to the other three members of the consortium as well as the Governments of Canada, Newfoundland and Labrador at approximately 1.30 p.m. today.
I want to assure the hon. member and this House, as well the premier of Newfoundland, and my counterpart in Newfoundland that the Government of Canada intends for the project to go head. As the hon. member and the House know, we as Canadians are standing behind the project with over $1 billion in grants and over $1.6 billion in guarantees and loans.
There is a structure in the unanimous agreement of the consortium, a method or a mechanism, whereby it will continue putting money into the project. It is the government's intention that the project continue.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance and concern's layoffs in the Atlantic provinces.

Routine Proceedings
The government's economic policies have ravaged the forestry industry in my riding, resulting in 300 layoffs in Atholville and 400 layoffs expected for the Dalhousie mill. The Government of New Brunswick has unveiled a strategy to help the forestry industry. What new measures does the government intend to take to solve the problems in the natural-resource sector, and when?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the forestry industry has indeed experienced a downturn not only in Canada but throughout the world. Commodity prices have been seriously depressed. As well there is reduced demand.
This is an issue that will be helped to some extent by the reduction of interest rates. I believe the lower burden of debt servicing will be helpful. My latest indication is that there does appear to be some upturn around the comer.
The housing initiatives that were announced south of the border and the housing initiatives that are being taken here in Canada will obviously provide some help in that regard.
I do not underestimate the seriousness of the problem and I can assure the hon. member that we are taking that matter seriously.

Mr. Speaker, my point of order refers to the second part of an answer during Question Period by the Minister for International Trade. The minister referred to a document. At first he did not acknowledge it existed but then he began to refer to it.
I want an explanation of the rules of this House on whether or not the minister, once referring to that document and perhaps alluding to quotes from it, is obliged by the rules of this House to table the document in the House.

I can assist the hon. member, and I will hear the minister in a moment. If the minister is reading from a document then of course the general rule is that he would be required to table it.
I will hear the minister.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to take issue with what my colleague has just said. I have never in this House not acknowledged that that text did exist. I have said on a number of occasions outside this House that the text did exist.
I am sorry that my friend is not reading the newspapers and understanding what is going on around him.

My point of order is not a dispute over whether or not the document exists. I have always maintained it exists.
My point of order is once a reference is made to it by the minister, is he obliged to make that document available to all the parliamentarians?

The point the hon. member is making is an interesting one. I have said that if the minister reads from the text of the document then the general rule is that it be tabled. If the minister, on the other hand, makes some reference to some document somewhere, the same does not apply.

Mr. Speaker, my question is whether you have taken a position on the words "hypocrite" and "stupid" which the Prime Minister used last November. If you have made a decision, I would like to know what it is.
The hon. member asks whether the Speaker has made a decision on a matter of concern in this House before Christmas, more specifically in October. The ruling was brought down yesterday.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: When the House took recess at one o'clock, the hon. member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell had the floor. We are now on ten-minute speeches, without questions or comments.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome the opportunity this afternoon to take part in the debate on a bill whose purpose is to amend the Canada Assistance Plan.
Mr. Speaker, as you know, this is the government's second attempt to amend this legislation. The first time, the matter ended up in the Canadian courts, and unfortunately, the government won its case. However, although according to the courts the government was acting well within what was permissible under the Constitution, that does not mean it was the right decision. In fact, the opposite is true.
We are going through a very difficult period in this country. We are now in a recession that is worse than the one we had in 1982, and one remembers what the Conservatives had to say about that one at the time. Unlike 1982, the 1991 recession started here in Canada. This is a recession we created ourselves here in this country, or at least most of it, because the world-wide recession occurred several months later.
The Tory government opposite was trying to slow down our overheated economy with its economic policies, but it did this so drastically that the economy went into reverse, and now the engine is stalled, and we still haven't found a way to get it started again.
Tbday, in one of his questions in the House of Commons, the hon. member for Dartmouth mentioned the bankruptcy rate in Canada. I think he told us there had been about 62,000 personal bankruptcies in this country. I know this is a concern not only for my colleague from Dartmouth and every Liberal member in
Government Orders
this House, but also for all Canadians who are going through these rough times.
One of the regions in this country worst hit by the recession, Mr. Speaker, is my own province of Ontario, where we have two main problems. First, the Tory government opposite and, of course, the provincial NDP government. What a nightmare it is, Mr. Speaker, to have such a government in Queen's Park. They are almost as bad as the people across the floor of this House, which is hard to beat. I must say, however, that Mr. Rae and his friends are on their way there, very close to succeeding as a matter of fact. This is something you understand, Mr. Speaker, I am sure.
The Premier of Ontario announced a few days ago that the province was in such dire straits that the socialist government of Ontario might have to cut social programs. Can you imagine such a thing, Mr. Speaker? At any rate, I will let Mr. Rae come to terms with his conscience over the next few days. Meanwhile, we could at least support its economy by granting Ontario its fair share of the Canada Assistance Plan, bearing in mind that the bill before us would limit to 5 per cent the increase in transfer payments to this province. That, of course, is a maximum.
In my riding, Mr. Speaker, the unemployment rate reaches 15 and 18 per cent. My colleague from Stormont-Dundas was telling me earlier that, in the Cornwall area, it would be closer to 18 per cent. That is terrible. The riding of my colleague from Renfrew-Ni-pissing-Pembroke is no better off, and the situation is as bad, if not worse, in Glengarry-Prescott-Russell, as all hon. members must know by now, considering how many times I have raised this issue in this House.
Last night I had the opportunity to meet in Hawkesbu-ry, with the Advisory Committee on Employment for Prescott County, and its members were telling me how bad unemployment was in their region. Considering that people have little hope of finding work in the near future, what is going to happen when their unemployment insurance benefits run out, now much faster than before thanks to Bill C-21 passed by the government opposite? These people will go on welfare, or "on the dole" as we commonly say in Hawkesbury. That is when the Canada Assistance Plan comes into play by providing the funds for welfare. Traditionally, counties or regional municipalities paid 20 per cent, the province 30 per cent and the federal government 50 per cent.

February 4, 1992
Government Orders
Now, with the cap on increases for the three provinces of Alberta, B.C. and Ontario, in my province of Ontario the provincial government will have to bear a larger share of the Canada Assistance Plan. What is going to happen, then? Other things are going to suffer. The provincial government might cut school funding. It will cut in various places and with the NPD in power at Queen's Park, we can expect anything in the months to come.
Meanwhile, Mr. Speaker, Canadians will have to do with less and less. The number of individuals living below the poverty level will increase, and all that as a result of the cap on the Canada Assistance Plan.

I remember that day last year. I believe it was last August 15 when the government won before the courts the so-called right to impose these limitations on increases to the Canada Assistance Plan. Just because it won that right in the courts does not mean that the government is morally correct in what it is doing. I could think of other words to describe this government, but in the new spirit of co-operation I will not use them in this House. I will just think them.
Here is what a few others had to say. Lise Corbeil Vincent of the National Anti Poverty Organization said of that day last summer that it was a very black day for the poor. She said further: "The poor will become more and more defenseless than ever as the already meagre level of government supports are cut further".
Viola Robinson of the Native Council of Canada added: "Many native Canadians already living in Third World conditions will only suffer more as cost cutting continues to be more important than human lives". That expresses what is going on and what this government is up to.
There is still time. The Conservative backbenchers across the way could use this new year and be more objective and less partisan than they have been in the past. They could look at this objectively and say no to this bill: "We will not put up with the Minister of Finance's nonsense".
We will not stand for this. We want the poor in Canada to have a decent living. We want those poor people who
are living in the three provinces affected not to have further cutbacks imposed upon them.
That is what the government could do now. We are all holding our breath for the day when the vote will come, several days hence, because many of my colleagues have important remarks to make about this issue.
When the vote comes I hope that I can count on all Conservative members to repent, to change their minds and to vote with us in the opposition to defeat the bill in question rather than to support the Minister of Finance and his wrong ideas. They could represent their constituents, for a change, instead of representing the government.

Mr. Speaker, I rise in the House to oppose this legislation which is designed to place a cap on Canada Assistance Plan payments to the so-called have provinces.
Since 1984 when the current government took over, many of those have provinces have been operating on the margin. It is hard to characterize them as have provinces any more largely as a result of the policies of this government. This bill in conjunction with the other limitations imposed on transfer payments and other series of mean-spirited Tbry policies have reduced many of those provinces to become unable to service the needs of those who require the services of the provincial treasury. I am thinking of students, the sick and the poor.
It is not unusual for Tory governments and for governments of this stripe to focus their attack on those who can least afford to share the burden: the poor, the sick, those who have very low incomes, and also those who are not responsible for the depression and for the economic circumstances that this country finds itself in.
We pointed out before in this House that the real fault and the real problem of the debt and the deficit do not lie with the poor, the people who are in receipt of the Canadian government programs. Statistics Canada has already told us, and perhaps it bears repeating in this House, who is responsible for the problems that Canada is experiencing with the imbalance between its revenues and its expenditures. It is not the poor. It is not the beneficiaries of social programs and government programs.
February 4, 1992

The real culprits who are responsible for creating the deficit have been demonstrated in the Statistics Canada report. That report showed that 44 per cent of Canada's deficit problems are due to tax concessions to the rich, the very rich and to profit-making corporations.
You can trace back through the years the increase in those tax concessions to those corporations with the growth of the deficit. That is where the problem lies.
Statistics Canada also said that 50 per cent of our debt problem and our deficit problem lies with the high interest rate policy that was followed by both the Liberal and the Tory governments over the last 10 or 15 years. That has created 50 per cent of our debt problem in this country.
Interest rates have now come down. Unfortunately, the people in Canada who are in the middle class-the workers in Canada-have been bled dry so they can not even afford to borrow money to kick-start the economy again. Fifty per cent of the problem of this country's debt and deficit are due to the high interest rate policies pursued by successive Liberal and Tory governments.
What percentage of the problem is attributable to social programs and to government programs? According to Statistics Canada it is 6 per cent.
I cannot understand why this government continues to look through the wrong end of the telescope and why it continues to attack those social programs and government programs rather than dealing with the real culprits who created the debt in the first place. These are the tax concessions that were granted to the rich and to large corporations and, of course, the high interest rate policy of the federal governments, Liberal and Conservative. That does not come from the NDP. It does not come from labour. It comes from Statistics Canada, the government's own statistics-gathering and analysing agency. That is where that information comes from. Why does the government not take a look at the advice provided by the people who were paid to give it advice and provide it with information and statistics?
I will tell you the reason. It is because this government is not driven by accurate information; it is driven by
Government Orders
ideology. That is why it is looking through the wrong end of the telescope and that is why it is focusing its attack on social programs, transfer payments, things like health care, education and programs for the poor in this country. Dealing with those programs is not going to solve the problem of the deficit.
Look at what has happened in this period between 1982 and 1992.1 watched a program called The Compton Report on one of the national networks coming out of the United States. It pointed out that between 1982, when the recession was in full force down in the United States, and 1992, when again it is in full force, the wealthiest 1 per cent of people in the United States doubled their income.
They were able to double their income through easy tax policies granted to them by the Reagan government and by the Bush government. The wealthiest 1 percent were able to double their income. For them, there was no recession. Recessions for us are boom times for the very wealthy. That is because of the programs that are brought in by Liberal and Tory governments, both in Canada and the United States.
We have to start looking through the other end of the telescope and identifying the real culprits. That is, we have to start taxing those who have never experienced a recession. We have to be getting the revenues back from them so we can start paying down the deficit.
I found an article in our Quorum magazine a few days ago which talks about the entertainment tax credit for business people in this country. It seems that one of my Liberal colleagues got in touch with the Revenue Canada people and he discovered such things that are given tax credits in this country are the pleasures of escort services, which are deductible as a legitimate business expense, the masseuses and lavish booze parties.
Companies can claim all of these things as entertainment expenses and deduct them from their income taxes. For those large companies, we are paying for escort services, we are paying for masseuses and we are paying for booze parties on their behalf.

February 4, 1992
Government Orders
It is quoted in this article that Phil Jolie of the tax department's audit branch has told The Sun that anything- escort services, a car, a trip to a hockey game, all of these kinds of things-can be deducted as entertainment expenses for business purposes. I am told that these kinds of entertainment expenses cost the people of Canada $1 billion a year in terms of tax credit.
Imagine, we are talking about allowing those kinds of services which amount to one-thirtieth of the total deficit in this country. We are told by the government when it makes an attack on these social programs that everybody has to sacrifice a little bit.
Why do we not make those business people sacrifice the odd escort service, the odd masseuse, the odd trip to the hockey game, paid for at government expense to the tune of $1 billion so that we can reduce our deficit by 30 per cent? That would be a beginning; that would demonstrate some sacrifice on the part of those people who, as I pointed out, have never experienced a recession along with the rest of us in this country.
Tory governments deal with depressions and recessions in precisely the wrong way, by going about a cost-cutting program, a restraint program. I think it is instructive if you look back in British Columbia during that period from 1983 to 1986 when the premier was Bill Bennett and his two most important advisers were Kim Campbell and Norman Spector.
That government at that time went through a process of cost-cutting that eliminated human rights legislation, that eliminated support for families, that eliminated all sorts of programs that were directed to improve the lives of ordinary people. Unfortunately, the government at that time said the reason it was doing this was to try to prevent the deficit from going up. In fact, those kinds of mean-spirited cost-cutting programs resulted in the deficit in British Columbia increasing and the debt of the province increasing rather than going the other way.
It is time we learned a little bit from history rather than having Tory and Liberal governments constantly copying history and making the same mistakes. I call on all members of this House to defeat this legislation and let us start attacking the real culprits who have created the deficit and the debt in this country in the first place.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be given the opportunity on behalf of constituents in my riding to speak for the allotted 10 minutes on Bill C-32.
This bill emanates from the February 26, 1991 federal budget which essentially limits the federal contributions to three particular provinces in terms of social assistance, federal-provincial shared social assistance programs, namely to British Columbia, Alberta and Ontario.
In terms of the financial consequences of this particular bill, it will mean that cumulatively over a five-year period those three provinces will suffer in the neighbourhood of some $2,135 billion in losses. In my province alone, estimated this year it will be close to $1 billion.
I would like to say just a few things in the permitted time. First, there seems to be a mind set in this government, in this capital, and Ontario being one of the three provinces, I will speak for my own province. There seems to be a prevailing attitude that somehow it is oblivious to the serious economic winds that are prevailing in the province of Ontario.
There is a feeling that somehow there is the belief that this province is somehow a fat cat province. I am not saying that it is clearly down and out or that it is even on its knees, but there seems to be an absence of reality that when we look at Ontario, or when we look at metropolitan Toronto, there is another tale to the economic realities.
I am just wondering whether anyone on that side of the House of Commons recognizes the record number of job losses, the record number of plant closures, the record number of people who are going from full-time work to part-time.
Does anyone recognize the record number of older workers who are being displaced and have nowhere to go? No one wants to invest or has less of an incentive to invest in a worker who may not be by any means old but 50 or 55 years old, who still has a mortgage to pay and an education for children to pay before retirement age, in terms of no adjustment programs for plants affected by the free trade.
What I am saying is that the economic picture of Ontario is not very healthy. At the same time we have a government that is very resistant to any kind of national stimulus. We had the announcement yesterday that the government has agreed to one of our proposals to go from a 10 per cent down payment when it is federally insured to a 5 per cent down payment. That is one aspect that is good, but it is only one aspect of many which should be implemented.
February 4, 1992

But the message basically is that government wants to stand back and hope that the market adjusts itself or that somehow it will be a consumer-led recovery.
When we and our colleagues are out in our ridings we know that it will not be a consumer-led recovery because people do not have the confidence nor the certainty to either invest or to spend that extra dollar. If they are doing anything, they are saving those dollars in their mattresses for a rainy day that is even worse than today. We cannot blame consumers, particularly given the strangulation of taxation at all levels that those consumers, those Canadians, are feeling right now.
Perhaps it is not going to be a consumer led recovery. Perhaps the Government of Canada does not wish to enter into stimulating the economy so that people can be put back to work, so that people can come off unemployment or welfare, so that revenues can increase. If we are not to have any economic blueprint, we on this side of the House are saying that the bare necessity, for goodness sake, is for the Government of Canada at least to maintain its commitment to funding social assistance programs that can assist those three provinces and the Canadians living in them.
If the government were to come through with a federal assistance package that would stimulate jobs, that would speak to some kind of adjustment programs for Canadians displaced by such things as the many plant closings in Ontario's backyard, if the government were to come through with some kind of retraining program for our young on one end of the spectrum and for our older workers on the other, perhaps some people in this House of Commons could begin to understand and rationalize why because of the national purse some of the moneys for social assistance can be moderated somewhat.
We are speaking of reducing federal transfer payments to the provinces to help Canadians with a number of social programs. At the same time the government is not willing to move on the economic front as its citizens, business and bank presidents are urging. You cannot have an attack on your social assistance programs while
Government Orders
you are also standing pat and doing basically nothing in terms of federal economic stimulus.
I would prefer to have the stimulus and a reduced infrastructure for social assistance. Why? Because I find that there would be a greater dignity if Canadians were to go back to work, if Canadians would be offered jobs, if Ontario can once again begin to export its goods, if the displaced worker can be retrained for a job of tomorrow.
I would rather prefer that initiative than having to argue on the floor of the House of Commons today for Ontario to get its federal dollars so that Canadians can be assisted through these dark times. I would rather argue for putting Canadians back to work.
We have argued month in and month out. We are having a First Ministers' Conference. We will be having a federal budget. I hope there will be some answers, practical answers, pragmatic answers, for putting Canadians and Canada back to work.
I am also saying that in the interim, before any real national initiatives, this purported national government has an obligation to its citizens, a contract with its citizens. A program was started in 1966 for a very good reason. The reason is that while you work you pay your dues in a variety of ways and deductions are put back into our social service infrastructure for a rainy day.
It is not only raining in Ontario and across the country, but it is pouring. Canadians in record numbers are becoming increasingly in need. All of us know that our riding offices-at least it is the case with mine in Ontario-are virtually being turned into unemployment offices. For the first time the middle class citizen is coming to our offices and we have to make calls to the food bank, the North York Harvest Food Bank, to provide at least a shopping basket for the weekend. These are not individuals who are irresponsible or feeding off the so-called trough. They are decent, hard-working Canadians who have never seen a day like they are seeing today. I am not saying this for dramatic purposes in the House of Commons; it happens in our offices week in and week out.

February 4, 1992
Government Orders
What is the message we can construe from that? The message I get is that they want this economy humming again and, if the government cannot or will not do that, then it should at least have a basic dignified commitment to a social infrastructure and a social net that will allow Canadians to land on their feet, to be prepared to survive and to be able to address the future with some degree of dignity and confidence.
It cannot take away the social programs and at the same time not stimulate the economy. That is not national leadership. It is an abdication of leadership of the worst kind.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to be able to rise and speak on the debate of Bill C-32, an act to amend the Canada Assistance Plan.
The Canadian Assistance Plan is a program that was created back in 1966 to permit the federal government to enter into some cost-sharing agreements with provincial governments for the provision of social assistance and for social welfare services for Canadians in need.
What does this bill really mean? It reaffirms that this government has failed to learn that it has to consider, along with the country's economic and financial deficits, the tremendous social debt and deficits we also face. It cannot ignore one in favour of the other as this government has done. It cannot abandon its social targets and social policy goals in order to accommodate some sort of blind, narrow-minded view that the deficit should be our strait-jacket. This government has made the mistake of not forging a balanced approach.
Another interesting thing is that so far the government has allowed only 17 minutes of debate at third reading of the bill. None of my 46 colleagues from Ontario in the Conservative government has spoken in defence of this bill; nobody from Alberta and nobody from B.C. They would be up here defending this bill if they really believed in Bill C-32.
Deficit reduction alone is not going to answer many of the real needs of this country on job training, on education and on research and development. Deficit reduction is not a policy that improves the skills of one member of our work force, nor does deficit reduction feed people waiting in line at food banks. For these challenges we need other policies: strong social policies on things like child care and balance with economic
policies. If we are to build a caring and compassionate Canada, we need those policies.
This government mistakenly believes we have the luxury in this country of waiting for the deficit to go down before we help the million and a half unemployed. We do not have that luxury.
This government mistakenly believes that if it sits idly by watching the deficit the line-ups at the food banks, as my colleague just mentioned, will disappear. They are not. They are growing longer.
This government mistakenly believes that blindly paying attention only to the deficit will somehow magically stop children from having to go to school hungry each morning. It will not.
What does this government say to the thousands of people thrown on to the unemployment line since free trade came in? "Sorry, we can't deliver the massive adjustment programs promised by the Prime Minister because we are watching the deficit". That answer is really not good enough. I say we simply do not have the luxury of playing which comes first, the deficit or the strengthening of the social safety net, a tradeoff this government is making every day.
While this government is focused blindly on just the financial deficit facing this country, what about the social deficit we face? One and a half million are unemployed. Thousands of more lay-offs are being announced every week from CP Rail to Air Canada, and today 1,700 at Exxon. Manufacturing plants are being shut down all across the country, moving to the U.S., and now the prospect of more moving to Mexico also looms.
I simply say again deficit reduction is not a social policy. Deficit reduction has obviously failed at making Canada a more just society. Just recently Statistics Canada realized and confirmed that despite world-wide prosperity while this government has been in office, the economic and financial well-being of middle-income Canadian families increased less than 1 per cent. Is that what the Prime Minister meant by imposing prosperity on every region of the country?
The government's narrow-minded focus on the deficit can disappear on notice it seems. Two days after this bill which cut social benefits for the neediest of Canadians was first introduced, the government found $236 million for a science project in B.C. on the eve of an election. In the same week it announced it would move 200 Public
February 4, 1992

Service jobs to Saskatchewan, again on the eve of an election.
For those Canadians who will suffer as a result of Bill C-32, this government's encouragement to belt-tightening while it locates hundreds of millions of dollars for chosen projects is really hard to believe.
Canadians are still a compassionate people. Their commitment to a caring, compassionate society remains. Their belief in equality of opportunity remains. Only their government has abandoned these traditions in the name of a narrow-minded short-sighted preoccupation with a deficit at the expense of a more balanced social economic and financial agenda.
The government uses the rhetoric of equality to mask an agenda that widens the gap between rich and poor through archaic tax changes and the slow elimination of programs. This is unacceptable.
In the end, what is Bill C-32? It is one more instalment on the Tory agenda which Canadians have been living with for seven years. It is an agenda which has as its main focus a sort of blind narrow-minded preoccupation with the financial debt and deficit, ignoring the social debt and also the deficit. It is one where market forces alone are supposed to carry the day and where survival of the fittest replaces the goal of a caring compassionate Canada and a more just society.
The result has been an era in Canada when tremendous social and infrastructure needs have been ignored. Quite simply, the issue we face today is one of restoring the sense of balance between economic and social goals on the national agenda. We cannot ignore the financial debts and deficits we face as a country, but neither can we focus on them exclusively and ignore the tremendous social debt and deficits we also will face as a country.
The message is that we in Canada have always had a balanced agenda focused on the long-term and in the national interest. We still need an agenda in this country which maintains the social contract by pursuing social polity goals along with economic policy goals.
In the end I hope Canadians will agree that deficit reduction is but one challenge we face and it is one goal among many.
Government Orders
A fair and equitable social policy agenda at the same time will keep our children fed, housed, and healthy. That will boost families, make our cities more liveable, and our hospitals and schools better able to provide services. A more balanced agenda will help prepare our work force for tomorrow and will do these things in balance with economic objectives.
In the end I believe Canadians will agree that deficit reduction fails miserably as constructive social policy or as a social polity of any kind.
I also think that Canadians agree that you cannot substitute deficit reduction for policies that actually help people. People are suffering from unemployment after seven years under this government. There were hundreds more in Montreal in recent weeks lining up at food banks. There are those needing clothing for their families, and those who must send their children to school hungry in the morning.
Are these the images of Canada that most Canadians think about each day? I dare say it is not, but it is another side of the reality being faced in this country every single day.
In the end I fear this government will never learn that you cannot pursue deficit reduction alone at the expense of all other policies: policies for the family, for the worker who needs retraining, for the single mother who would like to work but also needs child care. This government mistakenly believes you can, as a countty, throw out your social polity goals whether it be on child care, services to the poor, or adjustment programs needed because of free trade. You simply cannot do this and be left at the end of the day with the kind of Canada we have been trying to build for more than a century.
The Canadian people look to their national government to reflect their concerns and respond to their needs. That is why they were elected. Unfortunately Bill C-32 not only fails to reflect the true needs of Canada, it also reaffirms this government's failure at balancing deficit concerns, our economic and financial debt and deficit with social concerns.
This government would do well to consider a more civilized approach, one that takes account of deficit concerns but also accepts its social responsibilities. I would recommend that the government take its ideological blinders off, withdraw Bill C-32 and go back to the drawing board so that Canadians might again be able to look to their national government as a true reflection of values that we all share as a people. We need a more equitable society where economic as well as social concerns are part of the national agenda.

Mr. Speaker, the Canada Assistance Plan was the legal implementation of an agreement reached between the provinces on one hand and the federal government on the other. It was an agreement that recognized something that one of the early leaders of our party, Mr. M. J. Coldwell wrote about in a little pamphlet called Am I my Brother's Keeper?. Over the decades, Canada has been one of the leaders among world nations in saying that we are indeed our brother's keeper. We have been in the forefront in bringing in new legislation and programs to try to help those less fortunate than ourselves.
Members of Parliament should be very much aware of that history and record and very anxious to maintain our reputation among world nations, quite apart but in addition to wanting to help those among us who are not able to help themselves.
We all know some of these people. In every one of our ridings there are individuals who need some help from the rest of us. We cannot do it individually, so we do it collectively and through our governments.
The legislation before us now, Bill C-32, limits the amount the federal government will increase payments to certain provinces to 5 per cent. Where did that figure come from? Why 5 per cent? Why not 4 per cent? Why not 6 per cent? Why not 40 or 60 per cent? It is simply because the Minister of Finance of the day was trying to balance his budget. What about the budget of the people who are in receipt of social assistance?
This plan was the federal government's recognition and acceptance, public confession if you like, that it has some responsibility for people being on welfare in the first place. Certainly there are some who will always be there. Unfortunately, in times like this when there are a lot of people receiving social assistance, history seems to show that the longer they are on social assistance the longer they will remain there. When it goes from one generation to another, it is likely to go for further generations unless something is done to break that cycle. The way to break it is not by cutting back.
The provinces mentioned in this legislation, British Columbia, Alberta and Ontario, had booming economies at one time. Whose fault is it that the economy is not booming today? We all remember the Conference Board of Canada saying that for the first time in the history of Canada we are experiencing a made in Canada recession. It is a recession that was made by this government to further its own monetary policies, regardless of the cost to individuals, provinces, corporations in those provinces, and workers in those industries.
The government was determined, as part of its plan, to keep the value of the Canadian dollar up, and keep interest rates up in the hope that it could control inflation.
The people bothered by inflation were not the people on the lowest rung. They were barely getting by and inflation generally hit goods that were not of most interest to them.
These people are hurting more now and they are also hurting in what used to be called the have provinces. As someone said earlier, when those provinces were booming there was an inclination for people to travel to B.C., Alberta and Ontario because those were the best places to look for jobs. It did not always work.
I recall being in Newfoundland and hearing the story about the chap who went to Toronto because he heard there was work there. He stayed there for 15 months and then returned home. He never found a job. His statement to his fellows was: "I guess I must have been there in the wrong season".
It was not always easy to find work in those provinces, but certainly for a time they were the best places to go if you were looking for a job. People did flock to all three provinces and the population increased there. When the government tightened the screws and managed to create a made-in-Canada recession, there were far more people there going on social welfare than had ever been the case. The higher population loaded a greater share of the cost of looking after our brothers on those provinces.
February 4, 1992

The federal government created this mess by manufacturing this made-in-Canada recession. It is not fair for the government to wash its hands of the problem and say those provinces can afford to look after these people within their borders. At one time they might have been able to pay for the social programs, but they cannot now. It is not fair to those provinces, but more than that, it is not fair to the individuals involved. The governments within those provinces in particular are the ones that are hurting. The word is spreading across the country, of course. One wonders where the federal government is going to go next in this matter of cutting back on social assistance.
The governments in those provinces are having to keep down the rates of welfare paid to people on social assistance. They are cutting back on social assistance programs generally, which makes it even more difficult for them to survive. It is not only hurting their chances today, but spoiling their chances of improving their position at any time in the future, even when the economy does turn around.
The government is concerned about the cost of these programs. What about the cost of what we are doing to these individuals? What are we doing to our country when we increase the number of people depending upon social assistance who may never get out of that net again? That is hurting us. Can we afford not to look after those people properly? I suggest not.
Some of my colleagues have mentioned different ways the cost could be met. It is a relatively small amount. It is a lot of dollars in total but it is a relatively small amount that the federal government is saving by holding back on the money that is going to these provinces.
There are ways in which the government has let up in other areas. The government has let up, for example, in the way of taxing capital gains. The government has cut back on the rate of income tax being paid by the highest income earners. Of all people, they are getting the break. The government has given more tax breaks to people in the highest incomes by increasing the amount of money that they can put into RRSPs. They can pay tax on it some day in the future with the possibility that the government will give them further relief somewhere down the road.
Government Orders
It seems to me the government is making it easier for the people in the highest income brackets, while pleading poverty when it comes to helping those most in need.
We are our brother's keeper. The government has created this recession and has a responsibility to do something to make it easier for the people in the lowest levels of our society. Government created this mess and has a responsibility to do something positive. Cutting back, as we are, to those who most need help is not the way to go. It is setting a poor example in our whole community. It is building up problems for the future, not just for the individuals and the families of those concerned, not just for the children who far outnumber any other single group in the total social assistance group, but for us as well. When they suffer, can we really go around and pretend that all is well with us?
Canada has had a good reputation. More importantly, we have looked after those who need help most to some level. We could do better and we should do better. Any money that is given to people to help them survive is spent within Canada. It is not spent on holidays abroad. It is not spent on purchases of expensive imported goods.
The money turns over and over within our own country. We can finance it, we can do it, we must do it, we owe it to ourselves to make sure that we look after those in our own community who cannot look after themselves. We are our brother's keeper.

Mr. Speaker, the question one must ask itself today is why did the federal government wait until 1991 to control the growth of transfer payments to the richest provinces?
As early as 1987, Ontario was experiencing a full employment situation and was beginning to generate an increasingly stronger inflation which led to the recession that we now have. Following a long study on the nature of unemployment in Canada, the Canadian Labour Market and Productivity Centre said: "The main conclusion of our study is that, except for Ontario, the unemployment rate in 1987 is well above that which could explain a mismatching of vacancies and individual unemployed workers. In other words, there are still enormous possibilities for growth outside Ontario, to reduce unemployment through economic expansion".

Government Orders
What did the federal government do in 1987? The federal government capped equalization payments for the poorer provinces. It must be mentioned that since the Conservative Party was elected, transfer payments from the federal government have increased by 8 per cent in Ontario and by 3.5 per cent in Quebec. At a time when Ontario still had full employment, the federal government was still supporting the economy of that province by adding hundreds of millions in transfer payments while it had decided, as early as 1987, to cap the equalization payments to provinces that could still create jobs and that needed those jobs. Since Ontario enjoyed full employment, it was obvious that to promote economic expansion in that province would necessarily fuel inflation. That inflation would have to be controlled some day and, of course, it was controlled in an excessive way.
Today, a province that was prosperous before, namely Ontario, finds itself in a relatively catastrophic situation from a budgetary point of view. For this year only, the federal government just cut $3 billion in transfers, when we are in a recession and when the unemployment rate stands at 10 per cent. How can you explain that this government did not take appropriate action as early as 1987? If it had, the inflation rate would have been much lower in Ontario and we could have implemented an expansion policy elsewhere, as well as create the necessary jobs. Whether in the maritimes or in Quebec, there were still great possibilities for expansion because the unemployment rate was high.
Rather, the government immediately reduced the transfer payments to the poorer provinces and then waited, probably because Mr. Peterson was a friend, until the situation got out of control. Why do this in 1991 when, on the contrary, we should promote economic recovery? Mr. Speaker, the reason is simple: The federal government has no room to manoeuvre. The federal government is no longer able to stimulate the economy and to dissipate this gloom among consumers. The only option left now for the federal government is the one it is implementing, that is to discourage even more those who have lost their jobs and to make the budgets of the provinces unbearable. In the next few weeks, we will have a chance to see the federal budget. We can indeed expect the deficit to be contained now. Why will the federal deficit be contained? For a very simple reason: Because \vith legislation like this and previous decisions to limit equalization payments and payments to the
provinces for health services, the federal government has transferred its deficit to the provinces.
From now on, the federal deficit can be controlled, but people will not feel any better about it. The provinces will have to pick up the slack. They will have to overtax and do what they have started to do, pass the buck to the municipalities, which will also have to raise their taxes.
In his New Year's message, the Prime Minister told us that Canadians are taxed enough. So of course the federal government won't impose any new taxes. Of course the federal government has done everything to ensure that the provinces and municipalities will have to tax in future.
People who live in Montreal or any community in Quebec will soon receive their municipal tax bills. Wait till they see the percentage increase. The Government of Quebec, of course, will pass this bill on to the municipalities because it has been burned by the federal government's refusal to maintain the tax agreements it had made.
Today a parliamentary committee on financing health services began in Quebec City. A shortfall of $200 million to $400 million is expected next year if health services are to be funded at their present level.
The federal government's cuts in transfer payments alone amount to $1 billion. Of course, spending must be limited across the board. The deficits must be limited. When the federal government passes this deficit on to the provinces, it does not solve the problem for the public. People have to live somewhere. Quebecers will have to pay more to Quebec or to their municipal government. That does not solve the problems, Mr. Speaker.
The federal government's drastic measures take much more from the provinces than from itself. Transfers to the provinces make up 22 per cent of the federal budget, but cuts to the provinces account for 33 per cent of the federal spending reductions.
Give Quebecers the choice now: Do you want to cut health services or the military budget? That's not hard, the answer is obvious. However, we do not have that choice. We do not have the choice because the federal government has decided to cut health care in an underhanded way, despite the fiscal agreements with the provinces. On the contrary, the minister of health goes around saying, "We want to maintain national standards." He is sure that everyone must have services, but they do not pay anymore-the provinces do.

For us in Quebec, there is a simple solution for that: We want our own military budget. We want to be a real sovereign country that controls its total budget and can administer all its taxes and the people will be able to decide on a clear vision. Do you want to cut defence? Do you want to cut health care? Do you want to cut international travel? At present, it is a total mess with shared jurisdiction. You can announce generous intentions, as Ottawa does, fine health care standards that others pay for.
The Prime Minister, who adoringly follows President Bush, should at least take a passage from his latest speech. Mr. Bush asked Congress to stop giving member states of the American federation any mandate without the money to carry it out.
We have the opposite situation in Canada. National standards are to be raised. The federal government wants to increase its power with a little politicking, to give itself a good image; it will impose very high standards for health care, but the provinces will have to pay, the municipalities will have to pay.
You cannot make rational decisions or pass responsibility on to the citizens if one government can impose standards and another government has to pay.
