that Bill C-293, an act to amend the Canadian Human Rights Act, the Canada Labour Code and Public Service Employment Act (whistleblowing), be read the second time and referred to Legislative Committee H.
Private Members' Business
She said: Mr. Speaker, it is with a great deal of pleasure that I introduce this piece of Private Members' Business, the act to amend the Canadian Human Rights Act, the Canada Labour Code and the Public Service Employment Act (whistleblowing).
The purpose of this bill is to provide appropriate sanctions against retaliatory discharges by public sector employers of employees who report or blow the whistle on serious misconduct by their employers. In protecting employees acting in good faith, this bill would recognize that there are times when it is in the public interest to encourage employees whistleblowing, particularly when the public health and safety are an issue.
It is also important to note that this bill not only covers public sector workers, but because it would be an amendment to the Canada Labour Code, it would in fact protect all workers under federal jurisdiction.
The amendments to the Canadian Human Rights Act in this bill would amend the act so that it would be discrimination for an employer to punish an employee who, in good faith, disclosed illegal or unethical conduct by an employer. The act would be further amended to provide for the Canadian Human Rights Commission to investigate and report on a complaint.
The Canada Labour Code would be amended by stipulating that retaliatory measures for whistleblowing shall be considered unjust dismissals for the purpose of the code.
The Public Service Employment Act would be amended so as to stipulate that an employee is not necessarily guilty of disloyalty for disclosing matters through a complaint to the Human Rights Commission.
This bill is not about establishing mechanisms whereby workers would seek revenge on their employers. In fact, it is just the opposite. It is to protect workers from the revenge of their employers. An independent assessment of complaints by the Human Rights Commission would quickly separate the vengeful or frivolous from the serious complaint.
This bill is not about encouraging workers to skirt the existing avenues available to them to address their concerns such as normal recording procedures or grievance procedures. The mechanism in this bill would act as an adjunct to what already exists. It is the last resort and when all else fails and every other avenue open has been exhausted, then this bill provides the protection for the employee to blow the whistle.

Private Members' Business
What this bill attempts to do is to remove from workers the untenable choice they are currently faced with of either turning a blind eye to wrongdoing or sacrificing their careers and jobs. What we are talking about in this bill is protecting workers who blow the whistle on their employers for wrongdoing.
Whistleblowing is a practice whereby workers disclose situations where they know about or suspect the involvement of other employees, the organization or an area of the organization in illegal, unethical or unacceptable activities. It is not so much a mechanism to expose wrongdoing, but rather it is the establishment of safeguards and procedures whereby honest workers have an outlet to discuss their concerns.
By establishing an outside reporting mechanism, in this case the Human Rights Commission, workers who are unable or unwilling to discuss issues which they regard as improper with their employers will be protected from reprisal as well as having someone else offer an independent and impartial assessment of their concerns. The purpose here is not to turn workers into work place cops, but when faced with issues such as discrimination, harassment, fraud, malfeasance or cover-up, workers need and deserve the confidentiality and security of an independent agent in order that they can be secure in the knowledge that their concern would be dealt with seriously and impartially.
What is desired is the right of ethical employees to work in an ethical environment.
In the public sector it is the job of politicians, in particular opposition politicians, to oversee and scrutinize the operation of government. Indeed, in our system of government it is our duty to do this.
We do not expect, nor does this bill anticipate public sector workers to do our job for us. What it would allow is public sector workers to fulfil the responsibility they are charged with knowing that if they report wrongdoing they can do so without fear of losing their jobs.
This bill is not about enlisting public sector workers in the cause of opposition politicians. It is about ensuring that public sector workers, all workers, can do their jobs
with the knowledge that the best interest of the employees and the public is being served at all times.
There is ample evidence to demonstrate that workers suffer emotional and physical turmoil in attempting to deal with their knowledge of fraud, conflict of interest, rampant waste, pollution violations or other forms of illegal or unethical conduct.
It was reported in The Ottawa Citizen not too long ago that workers have been fired for reporting illegal activity on the part of their employer and they have no recourse even when their allegations have been proved true and the employer fined. The corporation pays the fine and it is back to business as usual, but the worker has still gone down the road losing his or her job and that is a tremendous damage to one's career for being honest and open.
An American study found that in the absence of any protection, 90 per cent of whistleblowers lost their jobs, 26 per cent sought psychiatric or medical care and 10 per cent attempted suicide. This is a horrible price to pay for being honest and expecting honesty from one's employ-
We have a case right here in Canada, and I am sure there are innumerable cases, but I would like to cite one that has certainly been before the media a considerable amount in the last number of years. That is the case of Dr. Pierre Blais. He was a research scientist at the bureau of medical devices.
He prepared an article for a U.S. medical journal raising questions about the breakup of polyurethane foam on the Meme breast implant. A version of Dr. Blais' 1986 article on the breast implant appeared in a September 1988 issue of Transplantation Implantation Today, a Canadian journal.
In January 1989 Dr. Blais learned that the polyurethane foam used in the Meme was first developed for use in industrial products such as air conditioners and carburetors. On January 6 bureau scientists recommended to the bureau and asked the Meme manufacturer to voluntarily remove the implant from the market until its safety could be documented. It was overruled by Health and Welfare officials higher up the bureaucratic ladder and instead Surgitek was invited to submit data.
er.

In January 1989, Dr. Blais wrote a strong letter to his department superiors strenuously recommending the Meme be removed from the market. In March 1989, Dr. Blais was ordered to sign an edited version of his memo. On March 6 he signed the edited memo. On March 9 he was instructed by his immediate superior to destroy his original memo and report. In July of 1989 stating unsuitability for employment in the Public Service, Dr. Blais was in fact issued an immediate dismissal notice.
Now subsequent events have in fact vindicated Dr. Blais, and yet Dr. Blais is still not in the employ of the federal government nor does he have any means to become employed again by the federal government.
He is a man whose career was on the line and in his case he has overcome that. But that is not the way we want people who work for us to be treated when they raise serious concerns.
A survey published in Industry Week magazine noted that 25 per cent of its readers said that their boss had requested them to behave in a manner they considered unethical. Most simply swallowed hard and did what was asked of them as they felt that they had no choice but to comply. This bill would give workers that choice.
If we take a look at the whole concept of whistleblowing legislation, we really are asking for public sector workers or workers under the jurisdiction of the federal government to have the right to report wrongdoing by their employer without fear of reprisal and knowing that their jobs are secure.
It also provides that the reporting would be done through the Human Rights Commission. We are not suggesting that public sector workers go out and make unfounded statements in the public that could be very damaging to Canada. We are suggesting that there be a forum under the Human Rights Commission where that worker could go and take his or her complaint. It would be independently assessed by the Human Rights Commission. After the independent assessment and if it were found that there was validity to the complaint, the worker would not find himself or herself subject to dismissal for having blown the whistle.
Private Members' Business
It is veiy interesting that the United States has this type of legislation in place. It has not resulted in irresponsible actions being taken by American workers. We are saying that it is very important legislation. It is very important for us as lawmakers to ensure that the people who work for us and on behalf of Canadians have the ability and the vehicle through which they can raise concerns of wrongdoing by employers.
In 1986 the Ontario Law Reform Commission, in its report on political activity, public comment and disclosure by Crown employees, concluded that government employees should not have to rely on the limited common law public interest defence alone if they are disciplined for whistleblowing but rather should be given statutory protection. That is what this legislation seeks to do.
This type of legislation should complement, not compete with, the other obligations public sector workers have to their employer, including confidentiality. It is very important that it be understood that we are not suggesting workers violate confidentiality in a public way. We are suggesting that there be a vehicle to protect confidentiality and to protect the worker's obligation to report a wrongdoing.
This type of legislation would enhance the accountability of the public sector, federal jurisdiction workers and government to provide another instrument by which government action could come under public scrutiny. After all, this is very much what Parliament is about. We have a responsibility to be subject to public scrutiny as do the departments and the people who work for us.
Federal jurisdiction employers like airlines, rail transport and truckers have a responsibility to be scrutinized for the public good and for the protection of the public, certainly in the area of the environment.
In closing, I would ask the hon. members from the other parties to consider this legislation very seriously. As parliamentarians I believe we should take pride in those who labour on our behalf and on behalf of the Canadian public. At the same time we should protect those honest workers who feel duty bound to point out wrongdoing by their employer but are unable to so today because of lack of legislative protection.

February 4, 1992
Private Members' Business
I would urge hon. members to support this bill so that Canadian workers under federal jurisdiction would be protected in carrying out their duties.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to participate in the debate on Bill C-293, a bill to amend the Canadian Human Rights Act, the Canada Labour Code and the Public Service Employment Act. This bill proposes what in common parlance is known as whistleblowing legislation.
This matter has been aired in this Chamber a number of times in recent years as a result of private members' bills and motions. Therefore not a lot new can be said that would in any other way add or clarify what has already been said. Indeed, in 1986 a bill almost identical to the one now before the House was tabled, was debated at length and was not passed.
I would like to say at the outset that I applaud the hon. member for Mission-Coquitlam for this expression of concern for efficiency and effectiveness in federally regulated institutions and particularly for the implied concern for the health and safety of workers employed therein. I share her concern and would be eager to support any measure that would contribute to the improvement of safety in Canadian work places.
Every year in this country about a thousand workers die and many more are seriously injured as a result of work place accidents and employment related illnesses. In addition to the pain and suffering that results, these accidents and illnesses take many billions of dollars out of the economy in the form of lost wages, lost production, equipment damage and compensation payments.
If Bill C-293 offered even a partial solution to this serious problem, I would gladly support it. Unfortunately the bill before us does not offer such a solution. If passed, Bill C-293 might obstruct an effective existing procedure under the Canada Labour Code for preventing potentially hazardous working conditions. It might even create an atmosphere of confrontation and hostility in certain work places, which could be itself a threat to worker safety.
I would like to explain how such a situation could arise by describing what happens under the present legislation when, in the words of Bill C-293, an employer is engaging in or is about to engage in conduct that would endanger the public health or safety.
In most such cases, under federal jurisdiction the employee would be protected by the right to refuse
dangerous work provision of the Canada Labour Code. If an employee has reasonable cause to believe that a particular work process or condition could be dangerous to himself, herself or to any other employee, the employee has the right to refuse to do the work without being subject to any discriminatory treatment because of the refusal.
In certain cases these conditions could have public safety implications. For example, a truck driver being required to drive in excess of the maximum permissible hours may pose a threat to employee and public safety. There are already clearly established steps that must be taken when an employee refuses to do dangerous work.
(1)	The employee must inform the employer of the refusal to work and the reason for it and also report the incident to the work place safety and health committee or representative.
(2)	The employer must then investigate the condition along with the safety and health representative or a member of the committee.
(3)	If the condition is not corrected to the satisfaction of the employee, a safety officer is called in to investigate the complaint.
(4)	If the employee still is not satisfied that the condition is safe or has been corrected, the matter may be referred to the Canada Labour Relations Board for adjudication.
Throughout this process the employee is protected from any discriminatory treatment, including dismissal because of the refusal to work in dangerous conditions. What is more, the Canadian Labour Relations Board has the authority to make the employer reinstate an employee who has been dismissed for this reason, rescind any disciplinary action and repay any wages the employee may have lost because of the employer's discriminatory action.
Furthermore, under the Canada Labour Code an employee who complains to the Minister of Labour about any irregular working conditions imposed by the employer may request that his or her identity be kept secret. In short, the intent of Bill C-293 in so far as it concerns the issue of work place safety in federally regulated institutions is already being met by existing legislation. The passage of Bill C-293 would not offer further protection to workers in these circumstances. In fact, it could even lead to confusion as to what process takes precedence.
February 4, 1992

Private Members' Business
This government takes very seriously its responsibility to improve safety and health in Canadian work places and over recent years has been implementing a policy to ensure that employers and employees comply with the occupational safety and health regulations that have been drafted into law. Fundamental to this compliance is the recognition that occupational safety and health is the joint responsibility of employers and employees. Mandatory joint health and safety committees have been established because we believe that whatever their differences at the bargaining table, employers and employees have a common interest in making their work place safer and thus more productive.
It is not assumed that all employers are model employers and that there are accordingly swift and strong measures that can be taken against employers when warranted. However, employers are given credit for acting responsibility in this area of common concern. It is recognized that it is the people who work in an establishment, employers and employees together, who are best able to ensure the health and safety of that establishment. Only an atmosphere of co-operation will help to ensure safer work places and less secretive management.
Bill C-293, if enacted, could well result in a hardening of attitudes that could work not for but against the speedy resolution of health and safety related problems in the work place. Instead of the co-operative resolution of work place concerns, this bill proposes resolving such matters before the Human Rights Commission quasi-judicial board with labour and management pitted against each other as adversaries. In my opinion this could only lead to more confrontation, less co-operation, less sharing of information on safety and health matters, and therefore greater secrecy and suspicion and more dangerous working environments for Canadians.
For these reasons I cannot support this bill. [Translation]

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would also appreciate an opportunity to speak to Bill C-293.

I listened to the member from Elk Island with great interest. I was hoping that at some point he would get around to talking about the bill. Perhaps time ran out and he was not able to do that. Maybe in another incarnation at some other date he will be able to talk about the bill we are in fact debating today.
I cannot say that the bill has absolutely nothing to do with what the member talked about because there are one or two lines in the bill which come somewhat close, I suppose, to the issue referred. Again, it is only in a very general way.
This bill provides protection for people who are trying to act in the best public interest. That is what it has to do and little or nothing else. It provides for means to protect people who are employees of the public sector and who feel morally bound to protect the interests of the public.
There is always a difficulty for anyone who is a public servant. Who is the boss? The person who is a supervisor or the public, the taxpayers who are footing the bill? What happens when the two come in conflict?
Whose side does that employee who sees something wrong take, the side of what is good and proper or the side of the boss, when they believe in good conscience that those two sides are different from one another?
I think as a general principle all of us who represent the public interest in this House should believe in our conscience that it is not the side of the boss you take, it is the side of the public because it sent us here. That is a fundamental principle of our democratic system.
In order to provide that kind of accountability and those means, we need a bill such as this. Are there flaws in this bill? Probably. There are flaws in government bills all the time. That is not the issue. We can send this bill to committee and if we do not like it, we can defeat it there. However, I think in principle, I like it. I like some of the things it stands for.

Private Members' Business
If an employee, someone working for a Crown corporation, someone working in a government department, sees the boss bringing home the refrigerator that belongs to the office, what does he or she do? It is a question which should be of import to all of us.
As the member who proposed this bill said quite clearly earlier today, there are the general common law principles that apply, but they are clearly insufficient. Why should someone who is defending the public interest in good conscience have to then defend themselves in courts and everywhere else for having taken what was right to start with? That is the difficulty with the absence of any kind of law that protects whistleblowers, which is what we call people affected by this bill, people who denounce wrongdoing in good conscience, having the firm conviction that what they are reporting was a wrongdoing to start with.
On behalf of the Liberal caucus, last fall I put out a document entitled Public Sector Ethics. One part of the document refers to just that. I am the party's critic for public sector ethics. My colleague from Nepean is our critic for human rights and she, I know, has very important remarks to make with regard to this bill as well.
I quote from this document:

"Considering the government's recent problems in connection with action taken by public servants, it is imperative to implement a policy that provides effective protection for public servants who expose cases of waste, corruption and bribery. Public sector workers should be able to blow the whistle on this type of misconduct in the Public Service, without fear of retaliation".

If someone has a vendetta against the boss or against a colleague and he or she invents or concocts an alleged wrongdoing in order to get another person in trouble, that person should be properly chastised and reprimanded for doing so. That applies with or without such a law anyway.
What we should all want as Parliamentarians is to ensure that we have the laws to best protect the public interest. Other jurisdictions, the United States for one and possibly others, have such laws to protect the people who denounce wrongdoing.
As someone who has received-how should I put it-a number of brown envelopes in my years in public office, I
know dam well that the reason those envelopes are brown and come in under my door early in the morning, or are sent overnight now in the anonymous fax mechanism which is the new brown envelope system in this country, is that people do that because they want to denounce something that is wrong.
As parliamentarians we have to verify those facts, but it is strange to note that approximately 95 times out of 100 the information that is provided to us is accurate. It is dead on. People are reporting things which they believe to be incorrect and most of the time are incorrect when they do report it.
Even without that protection now people are largely providing information that is accurate, except that without that protection you do not have to be a genius to know that many people cannot and will not report incidents of wrongdoing simply because of their own personal fear. I do not blame them for having that fear.
If you are a civil servant or a sole support parent in the Public Service or elsewhere with two or three children at home and you see wrongdoing and you know that your conscience tells you that you should report it, your conscience also tells you that you have to put bread on the table. If you do report it and get caught and lose your job, then where are you? Then where is your loyalty toward your own family?
There are sometimes conflicting interests and it is our duty to protect the public interest. That is the reason this bill should proceed and go to committee.
If the member for Elk Island or anyone else thinks that the bill has to be corrected at that point, there is ample opportunity to do so at that time, but it should go ahead, in my opinion.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise in support of my colleague's bill, Bill C-293, an act to amend the Canadian Human Rights Act, the Canada Labour Code and the Public Service Employment Act.
At the outset I want to say that I was amazed by the remarks of the hon. member for Elk Island, who was not even talking about this bill. This does not talk about health and safety. This talks about everything else but health and safety in terms of providing the opportunity for workers to blow the whistle if they believe that actions of their employer, whether that employer is the Government of Canada or is covered under federal jurisdiction, are wrong.

In other words, without the fear of loss of job, loss of income, loss of ability to support their family, they can say to the appropriate authorities, not over the radio, not through television and not in the newspaper, that there is something happening here that is totally unacceptable.
A number of years ago I worked with an individual by the name of Bob Norbom who was a quality assurance inspector at Fleet Aerospace. He put his job on the line because he felt that the quality of the inspections, the quality of the products going into aircraft that were being flown by Canadians as well as others, was less than what it should be. As a result of his actions, as a result of his bravery, he lost his job. He received death threats. He received harassment and eventually he had to leave his own community to find employment elsewhere.
Workers in this country need some protection and my colleague's bill provides the basis for that protection. It may not be perfect. Heaven knows every time the government brings forward legislation it never comes out the same way it started because it learns through the committee process. What we are encouraging this House to do is adopt the concept in principle and send it off to committee for further study, for fine-tuning, and then we will see whether it is acceptable in a new revised form, or the same form, to the House.
There are other areas that we have to keep in mind. A worker in a shipyard who is told by his employer to dump environmentally unfriendly chemicals into the water should have the ability to report that without fear of losing his job. A health care worker employed by the federal government should have the ability to say he does not think the packaging on that shipment of blood to be shipped from the hospital to a lab is safe and there is a danger to those who come in contact with it, that is, passengers in commercial buses in the winter months when blood samples going from clinics or hospitals to laboratories over hundreds if not thousands of miles are stored in the travelling compartments, not in the holds underneath, but up on the racks above the passengers. A
Private Members' Business
health care worker should have the ability to report that without fear of losing his job.
The same can be said for flight attendants, for pilots who are being told to do things in a way that jeopardizes their lives and the lives of their passengers, not in a traditional health and safety issue context, but in the fact that someone has not de-iced those wings. I believe very shortly we will have a report from the Dryden inquiry that will show the systemic reasons why that crash occurred. In part it was because of the pressure on the employees to go past the fine line.
Another example, and I realize I do not have all that much time, is that late last fall after Nationair locked out its flight attendants and decided to continue to fly, questions were raised by myself and others about the safety of that airline using unqualified, quickly trained personnel to replace the experienced crews being locked out by the company.
I received an allegation from a flight attendant who found herself having to travel back on Nationair from where she was on vacation because that was the only way she could return. She observed a number of things that she felt were safety violations. She came to me and I reported those in writing to the Minister of Transport and asked him for an investigation because at the same time there was a Department of Transport inspector on that flight. There was a question as to whether he was observing the same things that she was.
The minister has since, as of February 3, got back to me and outlined his response. What I find interesting, and it relates to this whole question of whether employees need some kind of protection, is that on January 14 my leader got a letter from the president of Nationair, Mr. Robert Obadia, which says: "As you probably know by now all of Mr. Angus' allegations were found totally false by Transport Canada".
I get my answer today from the Minister of Transport and it is dated February 3. Nationair's letter is three weeks ago. It is no wonder that employees in the federal sector want some assurances because how did Nationair know what was going to be in the minister's letter?

Private Members' Business
Three weeks ahead of time.

Three weeks ahead of time. Another reason, Mr. Speaker, why workers whether they be federal employees under the direct jurisdiction of either the Government of Canada or the Crown corporations, or workers in the private sector who come under federal jurisdiction need some kind of protection. They need some mechanism where they can go and say: "Look, I do not like what is happening. I am scared out of my wits that someone is going to be injured or someone is going to be hurt because of the actions of my supervisor or of my company," and they need that protection.
As my colleague said in her presentation in this House, it is not an automatic assumption, it is not an automatic publicizing of the allegations, it is a process that can be used to determine if what the individual is suggesting is occurring or is about to occur is fact.
I want to say in closing that the members on the government side should take a look at some of the other elements in government policy that provide for this very thing. In transport, when someone in the industry believes a safety violation is occurring, or a violation of the regulations of the act is occurring, there is a special phone number that they can call anonymously to report it, whether it is lack of de-icing, whether it is falsification of logs, whether it is falsification of maintenance reports. Any of those kind of possible violations can be reported.
All we are asking for is to give a similar mechanism to other workers in the federal Public Service, in the federal jurisdiction.

Mr. Speaker, I too am delighted to stand in the House and speak to Bill C-293, which is an act to amend the Canadian Human Rights Act, the Canadian Labour Code and the Public Service Employment Act on whistleblowing.
I,	as the human rights critic for the Liberal Party, feel quite strongly about this bill. I commend the member from the New Democratic Party for bringing it forward. Its purpose is to protect employees who in good faith report or blow the whistle on the serious misconduct of their employers. In this case the employer is the federal government.
The essence of this legislation has been called for over the past number of years and Canadians from coast to coast have grown more concerned with the conflict of
interest in public sector ethics as they have seen a dramatic rise in the allegations of misconduct. Public sector misconduct is directly related to public cynicism toward politics, the employees of the federal government and the politicians who are elected to this House of Commons.
Canadians have demanded better public policy to thwart incidences of abuse of public trust. Whistleblowing is but a small part of a much needed complete overhaul of legislation dealing with public sector ethics, but it is a very important step. As an example, in the United States there has been growing support for the protection of employees who act in the public interest by disclosing conduct by their employers that constitutes a breach of law or regulations.
Ten states within the United States of America have already initiated legislation that allows employees to whistleblow. Although all employees need whistleblowing security, the Public Service by its nature is even more susceptible to employer abuse. In the public sector, employees are working directly for those who pay their salaries, namely, the Canadian taxpayer and therefore have that much more responsibility to protect their interest to their fullest capacity.
Essentially, measures are needed to protect whistleblowers because whistleblowing can very easily become part of their jobs. Legislation such as that before us today is the starting point for bringing protection to those who know firsthand of government abuses. In protecting employees, this bill would recognize that there are times when it is in the public interest to encourage employee whistleblowing as long it is done in good faith. The Liberal opposition places public sector ethics high on the agenda. We have called for an effective policy to protect public servants who expose waste, corruption, graft and similar situations.
Public servants must be able to report illegal or unethical behaviour they encounter on the job without fear of reprisal. The Public Service Alliance of Canada has been calling for such protection for some time. Before the last federal election, they issued a questionnaire to all three of the major political parties. One question asked about whistleblowing. The Conservative Party responded that "adequate mechanisms are in place within the Public Service".
February 4, 1992

As the union representing for the most part non-management public servants, it is well aware not only of the misconduct that takes place, but of the retribution that can result when an employee feels compelled to report the waste or corruption or even the risk that results from that misconduct.
Following the forced back-to-work order that this government imposed on the PSAC workers last September, an abhorrent action in itself, the Public Service workers did in fact implement a whistleblowing system. Unfortunately, as it was in the interest of management for this system not to work, many public servants were afraid to use the service for fear of recrimination and reprisal. The incidents of misconduct that were reported, despite this fear, are evidence of just how necessary such a reporting system is.
As my colleague from Glengarry-Prescott-Russell mentioned, quite often we, as members of Parliament, will receive via under the door the unmarked envelope with such indications of misconduct within the Public Service. The public sector work in areas that have a direct impact on the health and safety of Canadians. They are involved in meat and food inspection, transportation inspection, airport protection and environmental concerns. They must be free of the fear of recrimination.
The Public Service Alliance of Canada, in its questionnaire to all three major political parties, asked this very question. But the number of reported cases of wrongdoing in this government over the last few years is testament to the fact that there is a dire need for stronger measures.
I would like to mention one case in particular with Health and Welfare where a certain employee raised questions on the Meme breast implant and the dangers it posed to Canadian women and he was fired from his job. As it turns out now, we all know that he was correct in that assumption.
Of course, whistleblowing protection should not be allowed to contravene the basic common law principle that an employee owes his or her employer the general duties of loyalty, good faith and, in appropriate circumstances, confidentiality.
Private Members' Business
For instance, an employee should not be able to publicly blow the whistle without first using every internal means available to bring an end to the misdeed that is being reported. It is imperative that safeguards are also maintained for the employer. Concrete evidence of wrongdoing that affects public health and safety must be evident. This sort of legislation must not be used as a means of getting back at a manager in cases of personality conflict or as a means of airing personal grievances. If managers are to do their jobs properly, they must feel secure that they will not be brought up before the Human Rights Commission if, with just cause, they reprimand an employee for his or her misdeed.
I have already said that I support this bill in principle. However, I do question one aspect of its implementation. The bill states that an employee, with reasonable grounds for believing that the employer is engaging in or is about to engage in conduct that would be illegal or contrary to public health or safety, may file a complaint with the Human Rights Commission.
When the Ontario Law Reform Commission presented its proposals for whistleblowing legislation in 1988, it called for the establishment of an office of special counsel. This counsel would be an independent office that would investigate each complaint, decide whether there was just cause to blow the whistle and, if the whistle was blown, would protect the employee.
The Human Rights Commission should most certainly protect victims of discrimination due to whistleblowing. However, misconduct should not be reported to them but to a body formed expressly for that purpose.
It is not just the employees of the federal public sector who need to be protected. Also in the case of the federal body, we do not have an ombudsman where any person may go and try to correct a wrong. This is a very badly needed area within our federal system. I for one would certainly support an omnibus bill that would give anyone within the Canadian public the right to question what is happening in the Parliament of Canada.
I appreciate the opportunity of speaking on this bill in the House of Commons.

Mr. Speaker, I rise tonight to deal with a subject that is certainly dear to some people's hearts, but I have to say it is not dear to the hearts of very many Canadians. What I refer to is the general suffering from our goods and services tax.
In this country today we have the world's most complicated tax system. This is passing strange when we recall that this government said that tax reform is essential to the well-being of the nation; tax reform, not tax penury.
We have heard from this government that harmonization with the provinces is essential to provide a fair tax. When he was referring to a GST for Canadians, the then Minister of Finance also said that harmonization would be the order of the day. However, we see that the gap between what was said and what was done is very large and this gap is very noticeable to very many Canadians because many of them are falling into this gap.
A few examples from the long rolls of misery caused by the GST are a two-tiered tax system, expensive to collect, nearly impossible to amend; a made-in-Canada recession, complete with an intractable economic malaise; the deindustrialization of our most prosperous
province and regional development a joke and an empty shell.
Small business has it right; small business has referred to the GST as a national tax tragedy. Compelling words from that sector which was supposed to benefit the most from the new era of tax harmony. The Canadian Federation of Independent Business survey estimates that compliance costs are in the neighbourhood of $10 billion. In general that $10 billion comes out of the pockets of the small business person, the man or the woman who runs a store, sells a product, the person trying to make a decent living in tough times, the person trying to make any living in tough times.
Big business did not have to pay for the system from which it has richly profited, and big business did not have to go out and assume the burden of the accounting costs or the other compliance fees; it already had the resources to do that. Did the government ever think of the comer store owner who used to do his or her own accounting until this bureaucratic behemoth was dropped into his or her lap.
Did the government ever think of someone in the service industry or the tourism industry or the transportation industry? Did the government think about cab drivers? I am sure that every member of this House at one time or another has to take taxies, and I can tell you and any of the government members opposite that if you want to know what the average Canadian thinks about this pernicious tax, come and take any taxi in the great city of Halifax. Let them know that you are a member from the government side and you will hear in words succinct and clear what the people of Halifax and Nova Scotia think about the GST. You will hear what they think you should do with it and you will hear why this government is held in such disrepute by ordinary Canadians trying to make a living, trying to survive, while their government appears to them to be systematically out to frustrate and defeat all their efforts.
Mr. Speaker, it is a shame and a scandal and the government has ,to act to make life a little simpler for ordinary Canadians.
Mr. Bill Domm (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister
for Science): Mr. Speaker, I am sure that the former speaker's constituents and the people in Nova Scotia will be happy to learn that the replacement of the manufacturers' sales tax-which this government did-was at the urging of all three political parties in all the committees which sat prior to the implementation of the GST.
February 4, 1992

She could spend her time to much more constructive advantage if she spent a little time talking to other Conservatives, Liberals and NDPs in the provincial legislatures. She could talk to our Conservative premier in the province of Nova Scotia and perhaps urge him to meld the tax with the federal tax. If she is really sincerely interested in saving taxpayers a lot of money she should do more to get the two taxes melded and therefore save 50 per cent.
She has already been advised by the minister responsible for the GST that the figures given by the Canadian Federation of Independent Business are a sham. I would refer the hon. member to Hansard of November 6 in which he makes those points, but I do not have enough time to repeat them.
Having said all that, it does not go unnoticed that our government now is getting letters back, as I am, from businessmen who find out that they like to get the GST back on their trucks and their cars and their phone bills and their heat and their rent and all of the things that they got no refund on when they paid the old manufacturers' sales tax.
There is a positive feeling out there despite the views of the member from Nova Scotia. There are positive views out there of the advantages of the refunds on the GST to businesses, and there are advantages out there to the tax credits given to those less fortunate and unable to pay the GST. I know senior citizens who pay no GST because their tax credit exceeds their purchases.
I think that she deserves to give this House more respect and spend more time lobbying the provinces and have the taxes melded to save 50 per cent of the GST.

Mr. Speaker, my concern is with regard to the premiums under the Unemployment Insurance Act which small business people must pay as well as employees.
On October 29, 1990, the then Minister of Finance stated: "If there is any shortfall, this will be made up by the government". He promised that the government would finance the deficit until the end of 1992 without raising the premiums. By 1993, it is supposed to be
Adjournment Debate
self-financing from the contributions paid by employers and employees.
That particular undertaking by the former Minister of Finance, who is presently the Minister for International Trade, has not been adhered to. The fact is that this undertaking by the government opposite has been broken time and time and time again. We are now in the midst of a major economic recession which has hit every community throughout this country. It is demonstrable in every region of the country. The economy is in a terrible recession, and what happened on January 1, 1992? The government across the way increased premiums for business people, employers and employees by some 14 per cent.
This may not appear to be a lot, but we are in the midst of a deep, biting recession today in Canada. There are increased costs for employers, and I make special reference to small businesses in this country. In my own constituency I think of all of those businesses in the service sector, the professions and anyone who has a job. Many of them do not have a job. The employees must also contribute substantially in this time of recession, thereby taking much needed money away from consumers, out of the economy, depriving Canadians and business from flourishing.
I hope the minister or the parliamentary secretary responding for the minister will give serious consideration to my request to have this particular measure revoked. It adds nothing to consumer confidence in this country. It adds nothing in terms of exacerbating the successes, if any, of small business in this particular recession. The government has adopted a very very negative measure with this increase in the premiums for unemployment insurance.
The Government of Canada has broken its commitment to the people of Canada time and time again. In the last number of years the unemployment insurance premiums have risen not by 14 per cent, but by 24 per cent. I ask the parliamentary secretary responding on behalf of the minister to give serious reflection, and in view of the present state of the economy, remove this increase for unemployment insurance premiums so that Canadians will have greater confidence and more cash in their hands. This would stimulate a very very weak economy.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member has asked whether the government intends to increase the premium rate for unemployment insurance.
I have said in the past, and I shall repeat now, that the Unemployment Insurance Act specifies a process for determining the appropriate premium rate. That process requires the Canadian Employment and Immigration Commission to review the status of the UI Act and make a recommendation. The government will make its decision on the basis of the commission's report, the current economic climate, the fiscal situation and the financial integrity of the account. In short, the government makes a responsible decision based on all the relevant considerations once the review process is completed. The government refuses to look at the opposition's recommendation to make hasty or ill-informed decisions.
As the government stated in its last budget, the UI program is one of the most important elements of Canada's social safety net. It recognizes that the account must be maintained in a healthy condition. This means the rates will eventually have to be adjusted in a manner to ensure the fiscal integrity of the account.

Mr. Speaker, do you remember just how you felt when you signed the offer to purchase on your home? Well, I do. I felt happy, excited, thrilled, but most of all I felt scared, darned scared because I really did not know if I was going to be able to afford to pay for that home. You and I are not alone and were not alone in feeling that way because most Canadians feel scared when they buy their home. They feel scared as to whether or not they are going to be able to purchase it or whether they will be able to finance it or find a mortgage for it.
That makes sense because in fact one third of all homeowners in this country could not have arranged a mortgage for their home if it had not been for something called mortgage insurance. One third of all of the homes in Canada were built with the help of mortgage insurance. The only mortgage insurance available right across this country was provided by the federal government
under the National Housing Act through the federal government's housing agency, CMHC.
Now, according to the cabinet's constitutional proposals, the federal government is going to get right out of housing altogether and hand it over exclusively to the provinces and the territories. If they do that, who is going to provide for the mortgage insurance which helped to build one third of all the homes in Canada? Certainly not the private sector. They will provide mortgage insurance in Toronto but they will not provide mortgage insurance in Calgary or Edmonton. Perhaps the provinces and territories will provide it. Perhaps we are going to have 10 provincial mortgage insurance funds and two territorial mortgage insurance funds instead of the one national fund that we have now. Perhaps, but do not count on it.
Who is going to provide for the home repair program that we have now for low income senior citizens? It is a program that is provided right across our country by the federal government. Who is going to provide for the urban and off-reserve remote housing for native Canadians that is presently provided right across Canada by the federal government through their housing agency, CMHC?
Who is going to maintain the 640,000 homes for low income seniors, for the working poor families, for disabled Canadians that form an essential part of our national social safety net?
If the federal government intends to get right out of housing and give it to the provinces exclusively, does it also intend to provide the provinces with more funding or with further taxing powers in order to enable the provinces to maintain the present national housing programs? If it does not provide more money and taxing powers, is it likely that the provinces are going to accept that housing responsibility?
Well, it is time to start talking about the facts. Mr. Minister, let us stop kidding the troops.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jean-Guy Hudon (Parliamentary Secretary to President of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada and Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the federal government does not intend to promote, and I do mean promote, any reduction in support for housing in Canada, but rather to recognize exclusive provincial jurisdiction in the housing field.

The proposal that the government put forward would retain federal responsibility for aboriginal people and for research and development.

In any case, it must be underlined that these are proposals that were put forward for discussion by Canadians. There has been opportunity for considerable public debate before the parliamentary committee and in the constitutional conferences. We hope that advice will emerge from the committee.
Depending on the views of Canadians, the government intends to discuss this matter with the provinces, including financial arrangements which may be necessary to enable provinces to carry out this responsibility. It would be premature to speculate on the outcome of discussions at this time.

Mr. Speaker, my concern is with the Hibernia project. I notice the latest development today is that Gulf Canada is pulling out of the Hibernia project. I suspect that is going to cause some concerns to the government and to all Canadians, perhaps.
The positive offshoot might be that there might be more Canadian content in the project.
It was suggested to me that 50 per cent to 60 per cent of the equipment and materials and products would be of Canadian content. The minister told me personally it would probably be in the vicinity of 60 per cent to 75 per cent.
My concern would be whether the percentage of Canadian content is skewed by the labour component which we certainly endorse and accept. We want people from Newfoundland to go to work. We appreciate that.
Tb test the waters, I went to St. John's to find out exactly why Algoma Steel lost a steel plate contract to a firm in Belgium when we feel that we are most definitely competitive in this product line. Our bid was so dramatically higher than that of the Belgian firm that we thought it had to be a case of dumping. We still believe that to be true.
Nevertheless, I was quite impressed with the people I met in St. John's, the government relations individual, the legal counsel, the project manager of contracts and
Adjournment Debate
the business manager. I met with all of them. I was very impressed and I think they are doing their level best.
At this time it is out of government control. It is at arm's length with deciding who shall get these contracts.
Without being too parochial I had concerns at first that only Algoma was concerned. But I have since had calls from other manufacturers, manufacturers that have spent as much as $100,000 and did not even get on the pre-qualifying bidding for the project. That has to concern everybody in Canada, but especially Canadian manufacturers who anticipated they would get some good solid contracts. Anyone who has spoken to me has suggested any other country would make dam sure that it would be extremely well represented and would gather the expertise so that it could export that expertise later on for other megaprojects across the world.
We believe that Canada has not been afforded that opportunity and many Canadian firms have been shut out simply because they could not gear up. They could not meet the very severe specifications of the project, which again we accept because they have to be very severe and stringent because of the safety concerns on the project.
Did this Belgian company buy or did it dump product into this country? Did it buy this initial contract so that it could qualify for all other steel contracts? The officials told me that they would rather deal with just one company than with all companies.
Algoma has suggested to ISTC, Industry, Science and Technology, that it should initiate a dumping investigation. That investigation I was told would take a week. Here we are a couple of months later. The investigation is not complete. I am not sure who is investigating.
Steel producers tell me they are in this together. They are concerned and they are saying Canada must be more involved, more representative of the firms that are losing these contracts. There is great concern out there and steel producers are in no financial position right now to proceed with these dumping charges. It is time consuming. It is very costly and they are asking the government for help. They need the help. The government must step in because they are just too cash strapped.
We are suggesting that the government has been too passive in this and we remain concerned about the Canadian content which is a target, not a regulation of the project.

speakeroldname: Mr. John A. MacDougall (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to respond to the concerns that have been raised by the hon. member about Canadians not receiving sufficient benefits on the Hibernia project.
Like all Canadians, I am disappointed when Canadian companies are not successful in winning Hibernia contracts, but members should also be aware that literally dozens of Canadian companies have won contracts to supply Hibernia projects. Of the over $400 million in expenditures of the projects to date, over 70 per cent have been Canadian goods and services. This is in excess of the 55 per cent to 60 per cent of Canadian content targeted by the project set out by the Hibernia agreement.
Members also should be aware that local content for the first oil and gas development project in the North Sea was only at 25 per cent to 40 per cent. By international standards, Canadian companies are therefore doing better than their Norwegian or British counterparts in similar points of development of the offshore development.
The Hibernia project is providing substantial employment benefits to Canadians. At the end of December,
something in the order of 2,400 people are directly employed on the project. Eighty-three percent of these are Canadians. Over 600 were employed in Montreal designing the top side for the project and an additional 1,100 were working the bow arm in the Newfoundland building, the construction site of the Hibernia platform. Another 416 are employed in St. John's managing the project.
While many Canadians are benefiting from the Hibernia project, I am aware that some industries have been disappointed that they were unable to make major Hibernia contracts. The steel industry is one. I can tell the member that the government and the Canadian Newfoundland Offshore Petroleum Board are aware of the industry's concerns and we are working with the industry to ensure that its contracts are addressed at the time and moment. For example, Canadian steel producers are very much in the running for a contract to supply 70 tonnes of reinforcing steel for the project.
